bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, February 7, 1948

div1.p: Hench writes Redd about obtaining research material from Henry Rose Carter, Jr.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, February 7, 1948
div1.opener:
February 7, 1948
Mr. H. Carter Redd
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
I have returned from a week in Georgia speaking at medical meetings
and am delighted to have your letters of January 23 and 26. How very kind of
you to write to Doctor Carter's son. I am taking the liberty of writing him
directly as I think it would be only a matter of courtesy on my part to ex-
press to him directly my interest and intentions. I enclose a carbon copy
of the letter. I do indeed hope that Doctor Carter, Jr., will allow you to
lend me the trunks. I have assured him that nothing will be lost, not a
single letter will be kept by me without his explicit permission.

What I usually do in such cases (and I did this before with both
the Reed family and the Lazear family) is to sort the letters in chrono-
logical arrangement and then go through them carefully. I set aside those
of medico-historical importance and then with the permission of the owner
of the letters, I have copies carefully made, mostly merely typed copies,
sometimes an occasional actual photostatic copy of a more important his-
torical letter. On occasion, I have had these copies collected in chrono-
logical sequence and have presented them to the owners of the letters, ar-
ranged in temporary binders so that they are really for the first time available
for ready reading.

Thank you very much indeed for sending me the copy of Reed's letter
to Doctor Carter of April 3, 1901.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
